Dealing With Strings in R Preface

Dealing With Strings in R Lingyun Zhang 2020-04-04 Preface I have studied Chapter 14 of the book, R for Data Science, by Garrett Grolemund and Hadley Wickham. I put my notes and other relevant stuff here.

1 Knowledge points We can use either single or double quotes to create a string. If string contains quotes, then first use single quotes and then use double quotes, e.g. 'Nelson Mandela said, "It always seems impossible until it\'s done."' Use \ to escape, e.g. '\\' gives the backslash. Special characters: '\n' (a new line); "\u00b5" (Greek letter \(\mu\)). Type ?'"' into console to find more.

2 Useful functions All the functions that start with str_ are from stringr package. library(stringr) String length: str_length(a_vector_of_strings) string concatenation: str_c(sring_a, sring_b) or paste0(string_a, sting_b). NB: use sep (e.g. sep = ",") to control how they are separated. Make a vector of strings become one string: str_c(a_vector_of_strings, collapse = "") or paste0(a_vector_of_string, collapse = "") Take a sub-string: str_sub(a_srring, start = ?, end = ?). Note that the start and end can take negative values. Change to lower- upper- or title-case: str_to_lower(), str_to_upper(), str_to_title() Trim white spaces in a string: str_trim(a_string, side = c('left', 'right', 'both')) Detect matches: str_detect(a_string, pattern) Get subset: str_subset(a_vector_of_string, pattern)

3 Regular expressions Firstly, what is a regular expression? The best way to answer this question is to give a few examples. Example 1: abc is a regular expression, it means a string abc. Example 2: . is a regular expression, and it means any a character. So, . is a special character in the regular expression system. Example 3: \ is a regular expression and it means escape. So, \ is a special character in the regular system. To literally have the symbol \, we use string expression \\\\. Example 4: \. is defined as the symbol dot in the regular expression system, and we use string \\. to express it. From the above examples, we should have noticed that we must learn these special characters by heart. special character match/meaning string for this symbol . any character \\. \ escape \\\\ ^ the start \\^ $ the end \\$ \d any digit \\d \s any white space \\s [abc] a or b or c [^abc] anything except a, b or c | logic operator “or” \\| ? zero or one \\? * zero or more \\* + one or more \\+ {n} exactly n {n,} n or more {,m} at most m {n,m} between n and m
4 Examples Change the first letter to lowercase Using noquote() Using str_detect() and str_subset() Removing a prefix Removing a suffix Roving spaces Using str_split_fixed Using filter and str_detect

4 Examples Change the first letter to lowercase library(stringr) fk_string <- c("Apple Pie", "Chocolate Cake") str_sub(fk_string, 1, 1) <- str_to_lower(str_sub(fk_string, 1, 1)) fk_string ## [1] "apple Pie" "chocolate Cake" Using noquote() fk_df <- data.frame(xyz = 1:3, yzx = 2:4, zxy = 3:5) list(names(fk_df), noquote(names(fk_df))) ## [[1]] ## [1] "xyz" "yzx" "zxy" ## ## [[2]] ## [1] xyz yzx zxy Using str_detect() and str_subset() library(stringr) corpus <- stringr::words (three_letter_words <- corpus[str_detect(corpus, "^[a-z][a-z][a-z]$")]) ## [1] "act" "add" "age" "ago" "air" "all" "and" "any" "arm" "art" "ask" ## [12] "bad" "bag" "bar" "bed" "bet" "big" "bit" "box" "boy" "bus" "but" ## [23] "buy" "can" "car" "cat" "cup" "cut" "dad" "day" "die" "dog" "dry" ## [34] "due" "eat" "egg" "end" "eye" "far" "few" "fit" "fly" "for" "fun" ## [45] "gas" "get" "god" "guy" "hit" "hot" "how" "job" "key" "kid" "lad" ## [56] "law" "lay" "leg" "let" "lie" "lot" "low" "man" "may" "mrs" "new" ## [67] "non" "not" "now" "odd" "off" "old" "one" "out" "own" "pay" "per" ## [78] "put" "red" "rid" "run" "say" "see" "set" "sex" "she" "sir" "sit" ## [89] "six" "son" "sun" "tax" "tea" "ten" "the" "tie" "too" "top" "try" ## [100] "two" "use" "war" "way" "wee" "who" "why" "win" "yes" "yet" "you" (seven_or_more_letter_words <- corpus[str_detect(corpus, "^.......+$")]) ## [1] "absolute" "account" "achieve" "address" "advertise" ## [6] "afternoon" "against" "already" "alright" "although" ## [11] "america" "another" "apparent" "appoint" "approach" ## [16] "appropriate" "arrange" "associate" "authority" "available" ## [21] "balance" "because" "believe" "benefit" "between" ## [1] "year" "yes" "yesterday" "yet" "you" "young" (end_with_x <- corpus[str_detect(corpus, "x$")]) ## [1] "box" "sex" "six" "tax" (start_with_vowel <- corpus[str_detect(corpus, "^[aeiou]")]) ## [1] "a" "able" "about" "absolute" "accept" ## [1] "bed" "hundred" "red" (end_with_ing_or_ise <- corpus[str_detect(corpus, "(ing)|(ise)$")]) ## [1] "advertise" "bring" "during" "evening" "exercise" ## [6] "king" "meaning" "morning" "otherwise" "practise" ## [11] "raise" "realise" "ring" "rise" "sing" ## [16] "single" "surprise" "thing" (start_with_3_consonants <- corpus[str_detect(corpus, "^[^aeiou]{3}")]) ## [1] "Christ" "Christmas" "dry" "fly" "mrs" ## [1] "beauty" "obvious" "previous" "quiet" "serious" "various" (two_or_more_vowel_consonant_pairs_in_a_row <- corpus[str_detect(corpus, "([aeiou][^aeiou]){2,}")]) ## [1] "absolute" "agent" "along" "america" "another" ## [1] "about" "accept" "account" "across" "act" ## [6] "actual" "add" "address" "admit" "affect" ## [11] "afford" "after" "afternoon" "again" "against" ## [16] "agent" "air" "all" "allow" "almost" ## [21] "along" "already" "alright" "although" "always" ## [26] "amount" "and" "another" "answer" "any" ## [31] "apart" "apparent" "appear" "apply" "appoint" ## [36] "approach" "arm" "around" "art" "as" ## [41] "ask" "at" "attend" "authority" "away" ## [46] "awful" "each" "early" "east" "easy" ## [51] "eat" "economy" "effect" "egg" "eight" ## [56] "either" "elect" "electric" "eleven" "employ" ## [61] "end" "english" "enjoy" "enough" "enter" ## [66] "environment" "equal" "especial" "even" "evening" ## [71] "ever" "every" "exact" "except" "exist" ## [76] "expect" "explain" "express" "identify" "if" ## [81] "important" "in" "indeed" "individual" "industry" ## [86] "inform" "instead" "interest" "invest" "it" ## [91] "item" "obvious" "occasion" "odd" "of" ## [96] "off" "offer" "often" "okay" "old" ## [101] "on" "only" "open" "opportunity" "or" ## [106] "order" "original" "other" "ought" "out" ## [111] "over" "own" "under" "understand" "union" ## [116] "unit" "university" "unless" "until" "up" ## [121] "upon" "usual" a_words <- str_subset(corpus, "a") ae_words <- str_subset(a_words, "e") aei_words <- str_subset(ae_words, "i") (aeio_words <- str_subset(aei_words, "o")) ## [1] "appropriate" "associate" "organize" "relation" (aeiou_words <- str_subset(aeio_words, "u")) ## character(0) Removing a prefix library(tidyverse) fk_data <- tibble(a_var = c("10 poor 1", "20 ok 2", "30 very good 3", "999 NA"), x = rnorm(4)) rm_prefix_df <- fk_data %>% mutate(the_prefix = as.numeric(str_extract(a_var, "^\\d+"))) %>% mutate(a_var = str_replace(a_var, "^(\\d+\\s+)", "")) rm_prefix_df ## # A tibble: 4 x 3 ## a_var x the_prefix ## <chr> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 poor 1 0.984 10 ## 2 ok 2 -2.10 20 ## 3 very good 3 0.290 30 ## 4 NA 0.589 999 Removing a suffix library(tidyverse) fk_data <- tibble(region = c("A region", "AB region", "ABC region"), x = rnorm(3)) ## Method 1 rm_suffix_df <- fk_data %>% mutate(region = str_replace(region, "\\s(region)$", "")) (rm_suffix_df) ## # A tibble: 3 x 2 ## region x ## <chr> <dbl> ## 1 A 0.713 ## 2 AB 0.107 ## 3 ABC 0.208 ## Method 2 rm_suffix_df <- fk_data %>% mutate(region = str_sub(region, 1, nchar(region) - 7)) (rm_suffix_df) ## # A tibble: 3 x 2 ## region x ## <chr> <dbl> ## 1 A 0.713 ## 2 AB 0.107 ## 3 ABC 0.208 Roving spaces library(stringr) x <- " this is a big space problem. " (x <- str_trim(x, side = "both")) ## [1] "this is a big space problem." (x <- str_replace_all(x, "\\s+", " ")) ## [1] "this is a big space problem." Using str_split_fixed library(tidyverse) fk_df <- tibble(string = c("NZTA: New Zealand Transport Agency", "PSU: Primary Sampling Unit", "NPD: Non Private Dwelling")) split_matrix <- str_split_fixed(fk_df$string, ":", n = 2) split_fk_df <- as.tibble(split_matrix) names(split_fk_df) <- c("name", "description") split_fk_df <- split_fk_df %>% mutate(description = str_trim(description, side = "left")) split_fk_df ## # A tibble: 3 x 2 ## name description ## <chr> <chr> ## 1 NZTA New Zealand Transport Agency ## 2 PSU Primary Sampling Unit ## 3 NPD Non Private Dwelling Using filter and str_detect library(tidyverse) df_1 <- data.frame(x = c("x-18", sample(letters[1:3], 3), "a-18", "b-18"), y = rnorm(6)) df_2 <- df_1 %>% filter(str_detect(x, "-")) df_2 ## x y ## 1 x-18 -0.83163701 ## 2 a-18 -0.31714041 ## 3 b-18 0.01725075
